abstract.text: A specialized view, such as a button or text field, that notifies your app of relevant events using the target-action design pattern.

inlineContent.text: class is abstract and must be subclassed to be used. Although you can subclass it yourself, more often you use one of the subclasses already defined by AppKit. A control draws content on the screen, automatically handles user interactions with that content, and calls the action method of its target object for any significant user interactions.
class provides several delegate methods for its subclasses that allow text editing, such as
defines delegate methods, it doesn’t itself have a delegate. Any subclass that uses these methods must have a delegate and the methods to get and set it. In addition, a formal delegate protocol
also defines delegate methods used by control delegates.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
An active area inside a control.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
An interface that displays a hierarchically organized list of data items that can be navigated and selected.
A control that defines an area on the screen that a user clicks to trigger an action.
A mechanism for displaying text or images in a view object without the overhead of a full
subclass.
A control that displays a color value and lets the user change that color value.
A button with a pull-down menu and a default action.
A specialized view, such as a button or text field, that notifies your app of relevant events using the target-action design pattern.
A constant for specifying a cell’s size.
A constant for specifying the position of a button’s image relative to its title.
A constant that indicates whether a control is on, off, or in a mixed state.
Terminates the current editing operation and discards any edited text.
The default action-message selector associated with the control.
The alignment mode of the text in the receiver’s cell.
A Boolean value that indicates whether expansion tool tips are shown when the control is hovered over.
The value of the receiver’s cell as an attributed string.
The initial writing direction used to determine the actual writing direction for text.
The size of the control.
Returns the current field editor for the control.
The value of the receiver’s cell as a double-precision floating-point number.
Performs custom expansion tool tip drawing.
Begins editing of the receiver’s text using the specified field editor.
Ends the editing of text in the receiver using the specified field editor.
The frame in which a tool tip can be displayed, if needed.
The value of the receiver’s cell as a single-precision floating-point number.
The font used to draw text in the receiver’s cell.
The receiver’s formatter.
A Boolean value indicating whether the receiver ignores multiple clicks made in rapid succession.
Initializes a control with data in an unarchiver.
Initializes a control with the specified frame rectangle.
The value of the receiver’s cell as an integer.
The value of the receiver’s cell as an
value.
Notifies the control that the intrinsic content size for its cell is no longer valid.
A Boolean value indicating whether the receiver’s cell sends its action message continuously to its target during mouse tracking.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the receiver reacts to mouse events.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the cell is highlighted.
The line break mode to use for text in the control’s cell.
Informs the receiver that the user has pressed the left mouse button.
The value of the receiver’s cell as an Objective-C object.
Simulates a single mouse click on the receiver.
A Boolean value indicating whether the receiver refuses the first responder role.
Selects the specified text range in the receiver’s field editor.
Causes the specified action to be sent to the target.
Sets the conditions on which the receiver sends action messages to its target.
Sets the auto-ranging and floating point number format of the receiver’s cell.
Asks the control to calculate and return the size that best fits the specified size.
Resizes the receiver’s frame so that it’s the minimum size needed to contain its cell.
The value of the receiver’s cell as an
object.
The tag identifying the receiver (not the tag of the receiver’s cell).
Sets the value of the receiver’s cell to a double-precision floating-point value obtained from the specified object.
Sets the value of the receiver’s cell to a single-precision floating-point value obtained from the specified object.
Sets the value of the receiver’s cell to an integer value obtained from the specified object.
Sets the value of the receiver’s cell to an
value obtained from the specified object.
Sets the value of the receiver’s cell to the object value obtained from the specified object.
Sets the value of the receiver’s cell to the string value obtained from the specified object.
The target object that receives action messages from the cell.
Sent when a control with editable cells begins an edit session.
Sent when the text in the receiving control changes.
Sent when a control with editable cells ends an editing session.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the text in the control’s cell uses single line mode.
Validates changes to any user-typed text.
A set of optional methods implemented by delegates of
subclasses to respond to editing actions.
A display of a calendar date with controls for editing the date value.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
A display of image data in a frame.
A visual representation of a level or quantity, using discrete values.
A legacy interface for grouping radio buttons or other types of cells together.
A display of a file system path or virtual path information.
An interface for configuring a rule-based list of options.
An object that controls scrolling of a document view within a scroll view or other type of container view.
Display one or more buttons in a single horizontal group.
A display of a bar representing a continuous range of numerical values and a knob representing the currently selected value.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
An interface with up and down arrow buttons for incrementing or decrementing a value.
A control that offers a binary choice.
A set of related records, displayed in rows that represent individual records and columns that represent the attributes of those records.
Text the user can select or edit to send an action message to a target when the user presses the Return key.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
Review unsupported symbols and their replacements.
Describes an integer.
Sent when a control with editable text ends an editing session.
Sent when a control with editable text begins an editing session.
Sent when the text in the receiving control changes.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
An
object posts the following notifications to interested observers and its delegate. Note that although the
class defines delegate methods, it doesn’t itself have a delegate. Any subclass that uses these methods must have a delegate and the methods to get and set it.
